@graph.rdfs:label: Computational Neuroscience
@graph.rdfs:comment: An interdisciplinary field that uses mathematical models and computational methods to study the nervous system. It encompasses the mathematical foundation of neural function, from atomic level modeling of single channels to modeling attention and complex behaviors.

@graph.rdfs:label: Neuron Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: A mathematical or computational representation of a neuron that describes its electrical and/or biochemical properties. Neuron models range from simple integrate-and-fire models to detailed biophysical models like the Hodgkin-Huxley model.

@graph.rdfs:label: Integrate-and-Fire Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: The simplest mathematical model of a neuron where the membrane potential integrates incoming currents until a threshold is reached, at which point a spike is generated and the potential resets. This model captures essential spiking behavior without detailed ion channel dynamics.

@graph.rdfs:label: Hodgkin-Huxley Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: A detailed biophysical model of neuronal action potentials that describes the dynamics of sodium and potassium ion channels. It is the basis for most other conductance-based neuron models and was developed from voltage clamp experiments on the giant axon of squid.

@graph.rdfs:label: FitzHugh-Nagumo Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: A simplified two-variable model of neuronal excitability derived from the Hodgkin-Huxley model. It consists of a fast voltage variable and a slow recovery variable, capturing essential dynamical properties while being more amenable to mathematical analysis.

@graph.rdfs:label: Compartmental Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: A neuron model that divides the cell into multiple spatial compartments to represent the geometric structure of dendrites, soma, and axon. Each compartment has its own membrane properties and compartments are connected by axial resistances representing current flow.

@graph.rdfs:label: Ion Channel
@graph.rdfs:comment: A protein structure that spans the cell membrane and forms a pore allowing selective passage of specific ions. Ion channels can be voltage-gated, ligand-gated, or mechanically-gated, and are fundamental to neuronal signaling and electrical excitability.

@graph.rdfs:label: Voltage-Gated Channel
@graph.rdfs:comment: An ion channel whose open probability depends on the membrane potential. These channels are critical for action potential generation and propagation, with different types having distinct voltage dependencies and kinetics.

@graph.rdfs:label: Sodium Channel
@graph.rdfs:comment: A voltage-gated ion channel that selectively conducts sodium ions and is responsible for the rapid depolarization phase of action potentials. Sodium channels have fast activation and inactivation kinetics and are targets of many neurotoxins.

@graph.rdfs:label: Potassium Channel
@graph.rdfs:comment: A voltage-gated ion channel that selectively conducts potassium ions and is primarily responsible for repolarization of the membrane potential after action potentials. There are many types of potassium channels with diverse kinetics and roles in neuronal excitability.

@graph.rdfs:label: Calcium Channel
@graph.rdfs:comment: A voltage-gated ion channel that conducts calcium ions and plays crucial roles in neurotransmitter release, gene expression, and various signaling pathways. Different types include L-type, N-type, P/Q-type, each with distinct properties and distributions.

@graph.rdfs:label: Calcium Dynamics
@graph.rdfs:comment: The complex spatiotemporal patterns of calcium concentration changes within neurons that serve as signals for various cellular processes. Calcium dynamics involve entry through channels, buffering by proteins, uptake by organelles, and extrusion by pumps and exchangers.

@graph.rdfs:label: Calcium Buffer
@graph.rdfs:comment: A molecule that binds calcium ions and regulates the free calcium concentration in the cytoplasm. Buffers can be mobile or fixed, have fast or slow binding kinetics, and include proteins like calmodulin, calbindin, and parvalbumin.

@graph.rdfs:label: Endoplasmic Reticulum
@graph.rdfs:comment: An intracellular organelle that stores and releases calcium, serving as the primary internal calcium store in neurons. The ER membrane contains calcium release channels (IP3 receptors and ryanodine receptors) and SERCA pumps that regulate calcium dynamics.

@graph.rdfs:label: Synapse
@graph.rdfs:comment: A specialized junction between two neurons or between a neuron and a target cell where information is transmitted. Synapses can be electrical (gap junctions) or chemical (involving neurotransmitter release) and are the primary sites of neural communication.

@graph.rdfs:label: Neurotransmitter
@graph.rdfs:comment: A chemical messenger released by neurons at synapses that binds to receptors on target cells and mediates signal transmission. Neurotransmitters include small molecules like glutamate, GABA, acetylcholine, and dopamine, as well as neuropeptides.

@graph.rdfs:label: Nitric Oxide
@graph.rdfs:comment: A small, lipophilic gas that acts as an unconventional neurotransmitter by diffusing freely through membranes without requiring vesicular release or specific receptors. NO is synthesized by nitric oxide synthase and acts over volumes containing many neurons, mediating volume transmission.

@graph.rdfs:label: Action Potential
@graph.rdfs:comment: A rapid, transient change in membrane potential that propagates along axons and serves as the primary electrical signal for long-distance communication in the nervous system. Action potentials are all-or-none events generated by the coordinated opening and closing of voltage-gated ion channels.

@graph.rdfs:label: Membrane Potential
@graph.rdfs:comment: The electrical potential difference across the cell membrane, typically around -70 mV at rest in neurons. The membrane potential results from the distribution of ions across the membrane and is fundamental to neuronal signaling and excitability.

@graph.rdfs:label: Spike Train
@graph.rdfs:comment: A temporal sequence of action potentials generated by a neuron, representing the output signal that encodes information. Spike trains can be analyzed in terms of firing rate, interspike intervals, spike timing, and temporal patterns.

@graph.rdfs:label: Burst Firing
@graph.rdfs:comment: A pattern of neuronal activity characterized by clusters of action potentials separated by periods of quiescence. Bursts can enhance synaptic transmission, encode specific stimulus features, and result from intrinsic membrane properties or network interactions.

@graph.rdfs:label: Stochastic Process
@graph.rdfs:comment: A mathematical model describing systems that evolve randomly over time, used extensively in computational neuroscience to model neural variability, channel noise, and synaptic transmission. Key examples include Poisson processes, diffusion processes, and jump-diffusion processes.

@graph.rdfs:label: Poisson Process
@graph.rdfs:comment: A stochastic process in which events occur continuously and independently at a constant average rate. Poisson processes are commonly used to model random spike trains and synaptic input, with exponentially distributed inter-event intervals.

@graph.rdfs:label: Diffusion Process
@graph.rdfs:comment: A continuous-time stochastic process with continuous sample paths, used to approximate neuronal dynamics when synaptic inputs are frequent and small. The Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process is a common example used for modeling membrane potential fluctuations.

@graph.rdfs:label: Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Process
@graph.rdfs:comment: A mean-reverting diffusion process characterized by a drift term and Gaussian white noise, commonly used to model subthreshold membrane potential fluctuations. The OU process has exponential decay toward a mean and is analytically tractable.

@graph.rdfs:label: Information Theory
@graph.rdfs:comment: A mathematical framework developed by Claude Shannon for quantifying information, uncertainty, and communication. In neuroscience, information theory is used to measure how much information neural responses carry about stimuli and to characterize neural coding strategies.

@graph.rdfs:label: Shannon Information
@graph.rdfs:comment: A measure of the uncertainty or surprise associated with an event, defined as the negative logarithm of its probability. Shannon information forms the basis for entropy and mutual information measures used in neural coding analysis.

@graph.rdfs:label: Mutual Information
@graph.rdfs:comment: A measure of the statistical dependence between two random variables, quantifying how much knowing one variable reduces uncertainty about the other. In neuroscience, mutual information measures how much neural responses reveal about stimuli.

@graph.rdfs:label: Fisher Information
@graph.rdfs:comment: A measure of the amount of information that an observable random variable carries about an unknown parameter, related to the variance of parameter estimates. Fisher information is used in neuroscience to quantify the precision of neural coding.

@graph.rdfs:label: Neural Coding
@graph.rdfs:comment: The study of how information is represented and transmitted by patterns of neural activity. Neural coding encompasses rate coding (based on firing frequency), temporal coding (based on spike timing), and population coding (based on activity across multiple neurons).

@graph.rdfs:label: Rate Coding
@graph.rdfs:comment: A neural coding strategy where information is encoded in the average firing rate of neurons over some time window. Rate coding assumes that precise spike timing is not critical and has been the traditional view of neural coding.

@graph.rdfs:label: Temporal Coding
@graph.rdfs:comment: A neural coding strategy where information is encoded in the precise timing of spikes, including the timing of individual spikes relative to stimulus onset or the relative timing between spikes of different neurons. Temporal coding can convey more information than rate coding alone.

@graph.rdfs:label: Population Coding
@graph.rdfs:comment: A neural coding strategy where information is distributed across the activity of many neurons with different tuning properties. Population coding can provide robust representations and enable disambiguation of stimuli through the collective response pattern.

@graph.rdfs:label: Neural Network
@graph.rdfs:comment: A system of interconnected neurons that collectively process information and generate behavior. Neural networks can be studied at multiple scales from small local circuits to large-scale brain networks, and include both biological networks and computational models.

@graph.rdfs:label: Recurrent Network
@graph.rdfs:comment: A neural network containing feedback connections where outputs of neurons can influence their own inputs through loops. Recurrent networks can exhibit complex dynamics including oscillations, multistability, and working memory, and are ubiquitous in cortical circuits.

@graph.rdfs:label: Synaptic Plasticity
@graph.rdfs:comment: The ability of synapses to strengthen or weaken over time in response to activity patterns. Synaptic plasticity is fundamental to learning and memory, with major forms including long-term potentiation (LTP) and long-term depression (LTD).

@graph.rdfs:label: Hebbian Learning
@graph.rdfs:comment: A learning rule based on the principle that synapses strengthen when pre- and postsynaptic neurons are active together (cells that fire together wire together). Hebbian learning is a foundational concept in neural network theory and has biological support in various plasticity mechanisms.

@graph.rdfs:label: Spike-Timing-Dependent Plasticity
@graph.rdfs:comment: A form of synaptic plasticity where the direction and magnitude of synaptic change depends on the precise timing between presynaptic and postsynaptic spikes. STDP provides a temporally asymmetric learning rule that can lead to competitive dynamics and temporal sequence learning.

@graph.rdfs:label: Working Memory
@graph.rdfs:comment: A cognitive system for temporarily holding and manipulating information, implemented in the brain through persistent neural activity. Working memory is associated with prefrontal cortex and involves recurrent network dynamics that maintain stimulus-selective activity after stimulus offset.

@graph.rdfs:label: Attentional Mechanism
@graph.rdfs:comment: A neural process that selectively enhances processing of relevant stimuli while filtering out distractors. Attention involves both bottom-up (stimulus-driven) and top-down (goal-directed) control mechanisms and modulates neural responses throughout the visual and other sensory systems.

@graph.rdfs:label: Saliency Map
@graph.rdfs:comment: A topographic representation encoding stimulus conspicuousness that guides attentional selection. Saliency maps combine information from multiple feature dimensions (color, orientation, motion) to compute locations that stand out from their surroundings.

@graph.rdfs:label: Hippocampus
@graph.rdfs:comment: A brain structure critical for episodic memory formation and spatial navigation. The hippocampus contains place cells that encode spatial location and supports the formation of cognitive maps of the environment through specialized circuitry including the dentate gyrus and CA regions.

@graph.rdfs:label: Place Cell
@graph.rdfs:comment: A neuron in the hippocampus that fires selectively when an animal is in a specific location in its environment. Place cells collectively form a cognitive map of space and their receptive fields can be plastic, changing with experience and context.

@graph.rdfs:label: Barrel Cortex
@graph.rdfs:comment: The region of rodent somatosensory cortex that processes tactile information from the whiskers (vibrissae). The barrel cortex is organized into discrete anatomical units called barrels, each corresponding to a single whisker, making it an ideal system for studying cortical organization and sensory coding.

@graph.rdfs:label: Motor Control
@graph.rdfs:comment: The processes by which the nervous system coordinates muscle activity to produce movements. Motor control involves sensory feedback, motor planning, feedforward control, and coordination across multiple joints, with contributions from cortex, cerebellum, and spinal circuits.

@graph.rdfs:label: Cerebellum
@graph.rdfs:comment: A brain structure critical for motor coordination, motor learning, and timing. The cerebellum contains more than half of all neurons in the brain organized in a highly regular architecture with parallel fibers, Purkinje cells, and climbing fibers.

@graph.rdfs:label: Dynamical System
@graph.rdfs:comment: A mathematical framework for describing how systems evolve over time according to deterministic rules. Dynamical systems theory provides tools for analyzing neural dynamics including fixed points, limit cycles, bifurcations, and chaos.

@graph.rdfs:label: Attractor
@graph.rdfs:comment: A set of states toward which a dynamical system tends to evolve from nearby initial conditions. Attractors in neural systems include fixed points (persistent activity), limit cycles (oscillations), and strange attractors (chaos), and play roles in memory and decision-making.

@graph.rdfs:label: Bifurcation
@graph.rdfs:comment: A qualitative change in the dynamics of a system as a parameter is varied. Bifurcations are critical for understanding transitions in neural excitability, the onset of oscillations, and changes in network behavior with varying input or coupling strength.

@graph.rdfs:label: Electrosensory System
@graph.rdfs:comment: A sensory modality in certain fish that detects electric fields, used for navigation, prey detection, and communication. Weakly electric fish generate electric organ discharges and detect amplitude modulations through electroreceptors, making them excellent models for sensory processing.

@graph.rdfs:label: Weakly Electric Fish
@graph.rdfs:comment: Fish species that generate weak electric fields for electrolocation and communication, including gymnotiform and mormyrid fish. These animals have specialized electrosensory systems and have been extensively studied for understanding sensory processing, burst coding, and feature extraction.

@graph.rdfs:label: Pyramidal Cell
@graph.rdfs:comment: The principal excitatory neuron type in the cerebral cortex and hippocampus, characterized by a pyramidal-shaped soma and extensive dendritic arbors. Pyramidal cells integrate inputs across their dendrites and are the main source of cortical output.

@graph.rdfs:label: Dendrite
@graph.rdfs:comment: A branching extension of a neuron that receives synaptic inputs from other neurons. Dendrites actively process information through voltage-gated channels, calcium dynamics, and nonlinear integration, contributing significantly to neuronal computation.

@graph.rdfs:label: Visual Cortex
@graph.rdfs:comment: The region of cerebral cortex dedicated to processing visual information, organized hierarchically from primary visual cortex (V1) through multiple higher visual areas. The visual cortex contains neurons selective for features like orientation, direction of motion, and color.

@graph.rdfs:label: Fly Motion Vision System
@graph.rdfs:comment: The visual motion processing pathway in flies, involving the compound eye, optic lobe ganglia, and lobula plate tangential cells. This system implements correlation-type motion detection and has been extensively modeled, providing insights into biological motion computation.

@graph.rdfs:label: Correlation Detector
@graph.rdfs:comment: A computational mechanism for detecting visual motion by correlating signals from neighboring spatial locations after temporal filtering. The Hassenstein-Reichardt correlator is a classic model that explains motion detection in insects and has also been applied to vertebrate vision.

@graph.rdfs:label: Likelihood Method
@graph.rdfs:comment: A statistical framework for parameter estimation and model selection based on the likelihood function. In neuroscience, likelihood methods are used for analyzing spike train data, fitting point process models, and performing maximum likelihood estimation.

@graph.rdfs:label: Point Process
@graph.rdfs:comment: A mathematical model for sequences of events occurring at discrete times, such as neural spike trains. Point processes are characterized by their conditional intensity function and include renewal processes, inhomogeneous Poisson processes, and more general history-dependent processes.

@graph.rdfs:label: Conditional Intensity Function
@graph.rdfs:comment: A history-dependent rate function that characterizes the instantaneous probability of a spike occurring given the past activity. The conditional intensity function completely specifies a point process model and is central to likelihood-based analysis of spike trains.

@graph.rdfs:label: has model
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates a neuron or neural system to a mathematical or computational model that describes its behavior. This property connects biological entities to their formal representations used in analysis and simulation.

@graph.rdfs:label: uses ion channel
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates a neuron model to the types of ion channels it incorporates. This property specifies which ionic conductances are included in the mathematical description of neuronal dynamics.

@graph.rdfs:label: generates spike train
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates a neuron to the temporal pattern of action potentials it produces. This property connects the cellular entity to its output signal that encodes information.

@graph.rdfs:label: encodes information
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates a neural response to the information it carries about stimuli or behavioral variables. This property connects neural activity patterns to their coding function.

@graph.rdfs:label: regulates calcium
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates a molecular mechanism to its role in controlling intracellular calcium concentration. This property describes how pumps, buffers, and channels contribute to calcium homeostasis and signaling.

@graph.rdfs:label: exhibits plasticity
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates a synapse to the form of activity-dependent change it undergoes. This property describes which plasticity mechanisms operate at a given synapse.

@graph.rdfs:label: receives input
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates a neuron or neural structure to the sources of synaptic input it receives. This property describes the connectivity and information flow in neural circuits.

@graph.rdfs:label: projects to
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates one brain region or neuron type to its target areas or cells. This property describes anatomical connectivity and the flow of information through neural pathways.

@graph.rdfs:label: implements computation
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates a neural circuit to the computational operation it performs. This property connects neural mechanisms to their functional role in information processing.

@graph.rdfs:label: undergoes transition
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates a dynamical system to a bifurcation or qualitative change in behavior. This property describes how neural dynamics change with parameters such as input current or coupling strength.

@graph.rdfs:label: located in
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates a neuron type or neural structure to its anatomical location in the brain. This property specifies spatial organization and regional specialization.

@graph.rdfs:label: mediates signaling
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates a neurotransmitter or signaling molecule to the synaptic transmission it enables. This property describes the chemical basis of neural communication.

@graph.rdfs:label: has time constant
@graph.rdfs:comment: Specifies the characteristic time scale of a process such as membrane decay or channel kinetics. This property quantifies the temporal dynamics of neural and synaptic processes.

@graph.rdfs:label: has threshold
@graph.rdfs:comment: Specifies the membrane potential at which an action potential is triggered. This property defines the excitability of a neuron model.

@graph.rdfs:label: has firing rate
@graph.rdfs:comment: Specifies the average frequency of action potentials in spikes per second. This property quantifies the output activity level of a neuron.

@graph.rdfs:label: has conductance
@graph.rdfs:comment: Specifies the maximum conductance of an ion channel type. This property quantifies the strength of ionic currents in conductance-based models.

@graph.rdfs:label: has diffusion coefficient
@graph.rdfs:comment: Specifies the rate of spatial spreading for a diffusing molecule like nitric oxide or calcium. This property characterizes volume transmission and local signaling.

@graph.rdfs:label: has information content
@graph.rdfs:comment: Specifies the amount of information in bits that a neural response carries about stimuli. This property quantifies the coding capacity of neural signals.

@graph.rdfs:label: has buffer capacity
@graph.rdfs:comment: Specifies the amount of calcium that can be bound by a buffer molecule or system. This property characterizes the calcium regulation capacity.

@graph.rdfs:label: has synaptic weight
@graph.rdfs:comment: Specifies the strength of a synaptic connection, determining the amplitude of postsynaptic potentials. This property is modulated by plasticity mechanisms.

@graph.rdfs:label: Backpropagation
@graph.rdfs:comment: A learning algorithm widely used in artificial neural networks and also the name for action potential propagation backward into dendrites in biological neurons. In weakly electric fish, conditional backpropagation controls burst firing through dendritic spike dynamics.

@graph.rdfs:label: Hodgkin-Huxley
@graph.rdfs:comment: The groundbreaking biophysical model of the action potential developed by Alan Hodgkin and Andrew Huxley in 1952 based on voltage clamp experiments. This model quantitatively describes sodium and potassium channel dynamics and earned its creators the Nobel Prize.

@graph.rdfs:label: Reichardt Detector
@graph.rdfs:comment: A correlation-based motion detection algorithm proposed by Werner Reichardt for explaining fly motion vision. The Reichardt detector multiplies signals from adjacent spatial locations after temporal filtering and has been influential in understanding biological motion computation.

@graph.rdfs:label: Calbindin
@graph.rdfs:comment: A calcium-binding protein found in many neurons that acts as a mobile buffer for intracellular calcium. Calbindin has fast kinetics and plays important roles in shaping calcium signals and protecting against excitotoxicity.

@graph.rdfs:label: Calmodulin
@graph.rdfs:comment: A ubiquitous calcium-binding protein that acts as a calcium sensor and mediates many calcium-dependent processes. Calmodulin undergoes conformational changes upon binding calcium and activates numerous target enzymes including kinases and phosphatases.

@graph.rdfs:label: NMDA Receptor
@graph.rdfs:comment: A glutamate-gated ion channel that is both ligand-gated and voltage-dependent due to magnesium block. NMDA receptors are critical for synaptic plasticity, learning, and memory due to their calcium permeability and requirement for coincident pre- and postsynaptic activity.

@graph.rdfs:label: Ryanodine Receptor
@graph.rdfs:comment: A calcium-activated calcium release channel located on the endoplasmic reticulum membrane. Ryanodine receptors mediate calcium-induced calcium release and contribute to calcium waves and oscillations in neurons.

@graph.rdfs:label: IP3 Receptor
@graph.rdfs:comment: An intracellular calcium channel on the endoplasmic reticulum that is gated by inositol trisphosphate (IP3), a second messenger produced by phospholipase C activation. IP3 receptors mediate calcium release in response to metabotropic receptor activation.

@graph.rdfs:label: SERCA Pump
@graph.rdfs:comment: The sarco-endoplasmic reticulum calcium ATPase that actively transports calcium from the cytoplasm into the endoplasmic reticulum lumen. SERCA pumps are essential for maintaining low resting calcium levels and refilling intracellular stores.

@graph.rdfs:label: Long-Term Potentiation
@graph.rdfs:comment: A persistent strengthening of synapses based on recent patterns of activity, discovered by Terje LÃ¸mo and Tim Bliss. LTP is the most studied form of synaptic plasticity and is widely considered a cellular mechanism underlying learning and memory formation.

@graph.rdfs:label: Long-Term Depression
@graph.rdfs:comment: A persistent weakening of synaptic strength following specific patterns of activity. LTD works in concert with LTP to bidirectionally modify synaptic weights and is important for learning, memory, and homeostatic regulation of neural circuits.

@graph.rdfs:label: CA1 Region
@graph.rdfs:comment: A subregion of the hippocampus containing pyramidal neurons that receive input from CA3 via Schaffer collaterals and project to the subiculum. CA1 is critical for spatial memory and has been extensively studied for synaptic plasticity.

@graph.rdfs:label: CA3 Region
@graph.rdfs:comment: A subregion of the hippocampus with extensive recurrent collateral connections that receives input from the dentate gyrus and projects to CA1. CA3 is thought to function as an autoassociative network supporting pattern completion and episodic memory.

@graph.rdfs:label: Dentate Gyrus
@graph.rdfs:comment: The input region of the hippocampus containing granule cells that receive entorhinal cortex input and project to CA3 via mossy fibers. The dentate gyrus is thought to perform pattern separation, reducing overlap between similar input patterns.

@graph.rdfs:label: Prefrontal Cortex
@graph.rdfs:comment: The anterior region of the frontal lobe involved in executive functions including working memory, decision-making, and cognitive control. Prefrontal cortex neurons exhibit persistent activity that maintains stimulus representations after stimuli are removed.

@graph.rdfs:label: Primary Visual Cortex
@graph.rdfs:comment: The first cortical area to receive visual input from the thalamus, containing neurons selective for orientation, spatial frequency, and other basic visual features. V1 is organized into columns and layers with distinct functional properties.

@graph.rdfs:label: Middle Temporal Area
@graph.rdfs:comment: An extrastriate visual area specialized for processing visual motion, containing neurons with large receptive fields selective for direction and speed. Area MT integrates local motion signals and contributes to motion perception and pursuit eye movements.

@graph.rdfs:label: Lobula Plate
@graph.rdfs:comment: A neuropil in the fly visual system containing tangential cells that integrate local motion detector outputs over large visual field regions. Lobula plate neurons are direction-selective and mediate optomotor behavior and flight control.

@graph.rdfs:label: Eigenmannia
@graph.rdfs:comment: A genus of South American weakly electric fish that has been extensively studied for understanding electrosensory processing and neural coding. Eigenmannia generates continuous wave-type electric organ discharges and detects amplitude modulations.

@graph.rdfs:label: Apteronotus
@graph.rdfs:comment: A genus of South American weakly electric fish used as a model system for studying burst coding and feature extraction. Apteronotus pyramidal cells in the electrosensory lateral line lobe exhibit conditional backpropagation that generates bursts.

@graph.rdfs:label: Pinsky-Rinzel Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: A two-compartment model of hippocampal pyramidal neurons that captures burst firing through interactions between somatic and dendritic compartments. This simplified model successfully reproduces many properties of detailed multi-compartmental models.

@graph.rdfs:label: Kuramoto Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: A phase oscillator model with all-to-all sinusoidal coupling used to study synchronization in networks. Despite its simplicity, the Kuramoto model exhibits rich collective dynamics and phase transitions, providing insights into neural synchronization.

@graph.rdfs:label: Whisker System
@graph.rdfs:comment: The rodent tactile sensory system involving whiskers (vibrissae), trigeminal nucleus, thalamus, and barrel cortex. The whisker system is highly organized with one-to-one mapping between individual whiskers and cortical barrels, making it ideal for studying sensory processing and cortical organization.

@graph.rdfs:label: Vibrissae
@graph.rdfs:comment: The specialized tactile hairs (whiskers) on a rodent's snout used for texture discrimination and object localization. Rats actively whisk their vibrissae across objects at 4-10 Hz to extract tactile information about their environment.

@graph.rdfs:label: Series Expansion Method
@graph.rdfs:comment: An information-theoretic technique for estimating mutual information from neural responses with low spike counts. The series expansion approximates information using only first and second-order statistics (PSTHs and correlations), reducing sampling bias compared to direct methods.

@graph.rdfs:label: Maximum Likelihood Estimation
@graph.rdfs:comment: A statistical method for estimating parameters by finding values that maximize the likelihood of observed data. MLE has desirable properties including consistency and efficiency and is widely used for fitting point process models to spike train data.

@graph.rdfs:label: Ghost Burster
@graph.rdfs:comment: A reduced two-compartment model of burst generation in electrosensory neurons where the slow variable is reinjected near a saddle-node bifurcation. The ghostburster mechanism differs from traditional fast-slow burster models and produces increasing firing frequency within bursts.

@graph.rdfs:label: Optimal Control
@graph.rdfs:comment: A mathematical framework for finding control signals that optimize some performance criterion, widely applied to understanding motor control. Optimal control theory suggests that motor commands minimize cost functions combining task goals and effort, explaining observed movement patterns.

@graph.rdfs:label: Saccadic Movement
@graph.rdfs:comment: A rapid, ballistic eye movement that redirects gaze between fixation points. Saccades are controlled by brainstem circuits and their trajectories can be understood through optimal control principles that minimize noise-corrupted motor commands.

@graph.rdfs:label: Neural Correlation
@graph.rdfs:comment: Statistical dependencies between the activities of different neurons or between activity at different times in the same neuron. Correlations can arise from common input, direct connections, or network interactions and have important implications for population coding.

@graph.rdfs:label: Signal Correlation
@graph.rdfs:comment: Correlation across stimuli in the trial-averaged responses (PSTHs) of neurons. Signal correlations indicate redundancy in neural representations and reduce the information gained from observing multiple neurons.

@graph.rdfs:label: Noise Correlation
@graph.rdfs:comment: Trial-to-trial correlation in neural responses for a fixed stimulus, reflecting shared variability not explained by the stimulus. Noise correlations can limit or enhance population coding depending on their relationship to signal correlations.

@graph.rdfs:label: Coincidence Detection
@graph.rdfs:comment: A computational mechanism where neurons respond preferentially to synchronous arrival of inputs from multiple sources. Coincidence detection requires fast membrane time constants or specific conductances and is important for temporal coding and sound localization.

@graph.rdfs:label: Gain Control
@graph.rdfs:comment: A neural mechanism that adjusts the responsiveness of neurons to inputs, typically through divisive normalization or conductance changes. Gain control helps maintain optimal operating ranges and implements attentional modulation and adaptation.

@graph.rdfs:label: Neural Oscillation
@graph.rdfs:comment: Rhythmic patterns of neural activity at various frequencies including theta, alpha, beta, and gamma bands. Oscillations can coordinate activity across brain regions, gate information flow, and reflect the dynamics of recurrent networks.

@graph.rdfs:label: Gamma Oscillation
@graph.rdfs:comment: Fast neural oscillations in the 30-100 Hz range associated with attention, sensory processing, and cognitive functions. Gamma oscillations can arise from interactions between excitatory and inhibitory neurons and may coordinate neural assemblies.

@graph.rdfs:label: Neural Synchronization
@graph.rdfs:comment: The temporal alignment of activity across multiple neurons or neural populations. Synchronization can bind distributed representations, influence information transmission, and emerge from network interactions or common drive.

@graph.rdfs:label: Receptive Field
@graph.rdfs:comment: The region of sensory space that influences the activity of a sensory neuron. Receptive fields can be characterized in terms of spatial location, temporal dynamics, and feature selectivity, and can be plastic depending on experience.

@graph.rdfs:label: Spatial Receptive Field
@graph.rdfs:comment: The spatial region or set of locations where stimuli can influence a neuron's response. For place cells in hippocampus, this corresponds to the location in space where the cell fires; for visual neurons, the region of visual field.

@graph.rdfs:label: Feature Extraction
@graph.rdfs:comment: The process by which neural systems detect and represent specific stimulus attributes or patterns. Feature extraction can be implemented by neurons with selective receptive fields or by temporal patterns like burst firing that tag salient events.

@graph.rdfs:label: Synaptic Transmission
@graph.rdfs:comment: The process by which signals are conveyed from presynaptic to postsynaptic neurons at chemical synapses. Transmission involves calcium-triggered vesicle fusion, neurotransmitter release, receptor activation, and postsynaptic potential generation.

@graph.rdfs:label: Vesicle Release
@graph.rdfs:comment: The calcium-dependent fusion of synaptic vesicles with the presynaptic membrane, releasing neurotransmitters into the synaptic cleft. Vesicle release is probabilistic and its dynamics depend on calcium microdomains near voltage-gated calcium channels.

@graph.rdfs:label: Short-Term Plasticity
@graph.rdfs:comment: Rapid, transient changes in synaptic strength on timescales of milliseconds to minutes, including facilitation and depression. Short-term plasticity shapes temporal filtering properties of synapses and contributes to dynamic processing of spike trains.

@graph.rdfs:label: Neuromodulation
@graph.rdfs:comment: The process by which neurons adjust their intrinsic properties or synaptic strengths in response to modulatory neurotransmitters like dopamine, serotonin, and acetylcholine. Neuromodulation enables flexible reconfiguration of neural circuits for different behavioral states.

@graph.rdfs:label: Dendritic Spike
@graph.rdfs:comment: An active regenerative event initiated in dendrites, mediated by voltage-gated sodium, calcium, or NMDA channels. Dendritic spikes amplify synaptic inputs, implement nonlinear computations, and can trigger somatic action potentials or support burst firing.

@graph.rdfs:label: Backpropagating Action Potential
@graph.rdfs:comment: An action potential initiated in the axon initial segment that propagates backward into the dendritic tree. Backpropagating spikes provide a signal of output activity to dendrites, important for timing-dependent plasticity and can be conditional on firing frequency.

@graph.rdfs:label: Cable Equation
@graph.rdfs:comment: A partial differential equation describing how voltage varies along dendrites or axons, treating neural processes as cylindrical cables. The cable equation accounts for membrane capacitance, resistance, and axial resistance to model passive and active signal propagation.

@graph.rdfs:label: Numerical Method
@graph.rdfs:comment: Computational techniques for solving mathematical equations that cannot be solved analytically, including differential equations and optimization problems. In neuroscience, numerical methods are essential for simulating complex neuron models and networks.

@graph.rdfs:label: Finite Difference Method
@graph.rdfs:comment: A numerical technique that approximates derivatives using difference quotients on a discrete grid. Finite difference methods are used to solve PDEs like the cable equation and reaction-diffusion equations for modeling spatial processes in neuroscience.

@graph.rdfs:label: Molecular Dynamics
@graph.rdfs:comment: A computational method for simulating the physical movements of atoms and molecules by integrating Newton's equations of motion. Molecular dynamics is used to study ion channel structure, dynamics, and function at atomic resolution.

@graph.rdfs:label: Brownian Dynamics
@graph.rdfs:comment: A simplified molecular simulation method that models particle motion in a viscous medium with random thermal forces. Brownian dynamics is computationally efficient for studying ion permeation through channels and diffusion processes.

@graph.rdfs:label: Continuum Electrostatics
@graph.rdfs:comment: A modeling approach that treats the solvent as a continuous dielectric medium rather than explicit molecules. Continuum electrostatics using Poisson-Boltzmann equations efficiently computes electrostatic potential around ion channels and proteins.

@graph.rdfs:label: Decision Making
@graph.rdfs:comment: The neural process of selecting among alternatives based on evidence and value. Decision-making involves accumulation of sensory evidence, comparison to criteria, and selection of appropriate motor outputs, implemented by distributed brain circuits.

@graph.rdfs:label: Bayesian Inference
@graph.rdfs:comment: A statistical framework for updating beliefs based on evidence, where prior probabilities are combined with likelihood functions to compute posterior probabilities. Bayesian inference is proposed as a computational principle underlying perception and decision-making in the brain.

@graph.rdfs:label: Decoding Algorithm
@graph.rdfs:comment: A computational method for inferring stimulus or behavioral variables from observed neural activity. Decoding algorithms include maximum likelihood, Bayesian, and machine learning approaches and are used to read out information from population activity.

@graph.rdfs:label: Time-Rescaling Theorem
@graph.rdfs:comment: A mathematical result stating that a point process can be transformed to a unit-rate Poisson process through time rescaling based on its conditional intensity function. The time-rescaling theorem provides a powerful tool for goodness-of-fit testing of spike train models.

@graph.rdfs:label: Interspike Interval
@graph.rdfs:comment: The time duration between consecutive action potentials in a spike train. ISI distributions characterize neuronal variability, regularity, and refractoriness, and can distinguish between different types of coding and neural dynamics.

@graph.rdfs:label: Peristimulus Time Histogram
@graph.rdfs:comment: A histogram showing the average firing rate of a neuron as a function of time relative to a repeated stimulus. PSTHs reveal the temporal structure of neural responses and are fundamental to understanding temporal coding.

@graph.rdfs:label: Model Selection
@graph.rdfs:comment: The process of choosing among competing models based on their ability to explain data while avoiding overfitting. Model selection criteria like AIC and BIC balance goodness-of-fit with model complexity and are essential for identifying appropriate neural models.

@graph.rdfs:label: Goodness of Fit
@graph.rdfs:comment: Statistical measures assessing how well a model's predictions match observed data. Goodness-of-fit tests for point process models include Kolmogorov-Smirnov tests on rescaled ISIs and residual analysis.

@graph.rdfs:label: Sampling Bias
@graph.rdfs:comment: Systematic errors in parameter or information estimates arising from limited data. In neural coding analysis, sampling bias particularly affects entropy and mutual information estimates when the number of trials is small relative to response categories.

@graph.rdfs:label: Mean Field Theory
@graph.rdfs:comment: An approximation method that reduces the complexity of interacting many-body systems by replacing interactions with averages. Mean field theory is applied to neural networks to derive firing rates and dynamics from synaptic parameters without simulating individual neurons.

@graph.rdfs:label: Balanced Network
@graph.rdfs:comment: A neural network where strong excitation is balanced by strong inhibition, resulting in irregular, asynchronous activity despite high firing rates. Balanced networks exhibit sensitivity to input correlations and rapid response to changes in external drive.

@graph.rdfs:label: Attractor Network
@graph.rdfs:comment: A recurrent neural network with multiple stable states that can store memories or represent continuous variables. Attractor networks explain working memory, decision-making, and spatial navigation through their dynamical landscape of attractors.

@graph.rdfs:label: Bistability
@graph.rdfs:comment: A dynamical property where a system has two stable states for the same parameter values. Bistability in neural systems can support working memory through sustained activity states and arises from recurrent excitation or intrinsic membrane properties.

@graph.rdfs:label: Network Oscillation
@graph.rdfs:comment: Rhythmic collective activity emerging from interactions among neurons in a network. Network oscillations differ from intrinsic oscillations and depend on connectivity, synaptic dynamics, and balance of excitation and inhibition.

@graph.rdfs:label: Synaptic Integration
@graph.rdfs:comment: The process by which neurons combine multiple synaptic inputs to determine their output. Integration can be linear or nonlinear depending on dendritic properties, channel distributions, and the spatiotemporal pattern of inputs.

@graph.rdfs:label: Neuronal Compartmentalization
@graph.rdfs:comment: The functional subdivision of neurons into regions with distinct electrical and biochemical properties. Compartmentalization includes divisions between soma, dendrites, and axon, and microdomains within dendrites where local signaling occurs.

@graph.rdfs:label: Information Bottleneck
@graph.rdfs:comment: A constraint on information processing capacity that limits how much information can pass through a stage. Attention acts as an information bottleneck, selecting behaviorally relevant information from the massive sensory input.

@graph.rdfs:label: Conductance-Based Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: A neuron model that explicitly represents ionic currents through voltage- and time-dependent conductances. Conductance-based models follow the Hodgkin-Huxley formalism and can capture detailed biophysical mechanisms.

@graph.rdfs:label: Simplified Neuron Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: A neuron model that captures essential dynamics while being computationally efficient and mathematically tractable. Examples include integrate-and-fire, theta models, and Izhikevich models that balance realism with simplicity.

@graph.rdfs:label: controls motor
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates a neural structure to the motor output or movement it controls. This property describes how neural activity translates to behavior through motor commands.

@graph.rdfs:label: exhibits bifurcation
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates a dynamical system to a specific type of qualitative transition it can undergo. This property characterizes how neural dynamics change as parameters vary.

@graph.rdfs:label: modulates activity
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates a neuromodulatory mechanism or substance to the neural activity it influences. This property describes indirect effects on neural processing.

@graph.rdfs:label: detects feature
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates a neuron or neural mechanism to the stimulus feature it selectively responds to. This property describes feature selectivity in sensory systems.

@graph.rdfs:label: forms synapse
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates a presynaptic neuron to its postsynaptic target through a synaptic connection. This property defines the directed connectivity graph of neural networks.

@graph.rdfs:label: encodes space
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates a neuron to its spatial receptive field or place representation. This property is particularly relevant for place cells and spatial navigation.

@graph.rdfs:label: synchronizes with
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates neurons that exhibit temporally correlated activity. This property describes functional coupling that may arise from various mechanisms.

@graph.rdfs:label: adapts to stimulus
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates a neuron or synapse to adaptive mechanisms that adjust responses during sustained stimulation. This property describes short-term and long-term adaptation.

@graph.rdfs:label: integrates signals
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates a neural structure to the integration process it performs on multiple inputs. This property describes computational operations like summation or multiplication.

@graph.rdfs:label: exhibits correlation
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates neural responses to the type of correlation they display. This property distinguishes signal correlations from noise correlations.

@graph.rdfs:label: has receptive field
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates a sensory neuron to its receptive field properties. This property characterizes what stimuli drive the neuron's responses.

@graph.rdfs:label: performs decoding
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates a neural structure or algorithm to the decoding operation it implements. This property describes how information is read out from neural activity.

@graph.rdfs:label: has variability
@graph.rdfs:comment: Specifies the coefficient of variation or other measure of trial-to-trial variability in neural responses. This property quantifies neural reliability and stochasticity.

@graph.rdfs:label: has latency
@graph.rdfs:comment: Specifies the time delay between stimulus onset and the first spike or peak response. This property characterizes the temporal dynamics of neural responses.

@graph.rdfs:label: has precision
@graph.rdfs:comment: Specifies the temporal precision of spike timing, typically in milliseconds. This property indicates the time scale at which timing information is encoded.

@graph.rdfs:label: has capacity
@graph.rdfs:comment: Specifies the storage or processing capacity of a neural system, measured in bits or number of patterns. This property quantifies memory or coding capacity.

@graph.rdfs:label: has eigenvalue
@graph.rdfs:comment: Specifies eigenvalues of linearized dynamics around fixed points. This property characterizes stability and oscillatory behavior of neural systems.

@graph.rdfs:label: has refractory period
@graph.rdfs:comment: Specifies the minimum time between consecutive action potentials during which a neuron cannot fire again. This property sets limits on maximum firing rate.

@graph.rdfs:label: has amplitude
@graph.rdfs:comment: Specifies the magnitude of a synaptic potential, action potential, or oscillation. This property quantifies the size of electrical signals.

@graph.rdfs:label: has frequency
@graph.rdfs:comment: Specifies the oscillation frequency in Hz or the firing frequency of a neuron. This property characterizes rhythmic activity.

@graph.rdfs:label: Gramicidin
@graph.rdfs:comment: A small peptide that forms ion channels in lipid membranes by dimerizing. Gramicidin channels are highly selective for monovalent cations and have been extensively studied as simple model systems for understanding ion permeation and selectivity mechanisms.

@graph.rdfs:label: KcsA Potassium Channel
@graph.rdfs:comment: A bacterial potassium channel whose crystal structure was solved by Roderick MacKinnon, revealing the molecular basis of ion selectivity. KcsA contains the canonical selectivity filter sequence and has been a paradigm for understanding K+ channel structure-function relationships.

@graph.rdfs:label: Alamethicin
@graph.rdfs:comment: A voltage-gated peptide that forms ion channels in membranes through barrel-stave aggregation. Alamethicin has been studied as a model for understanding voltage-dependent gating and pore formation.

@graph.rdfs:label: OmpF Porin
@graph.rdfs:comment: A trimeric outer membrane protein from E. coli that forms water-filled pores allowing passive diffusion of small molecules. OmpF has been studied extensively using electrophysiology and molecular dynamics simulations.

@graph.rdfs:label: GABA-A Receptor
@graph.rdfs:comment: A ligand-gated chloride channel activated by the inhibitory neurotransmitter GABA. GABA-A receptors mediate fast inhibitory synaptic transmission and are targets of benzodiazepines and barbiturates.

@graph.rdfs:label: AMPA Receptor
@graph.rdfs:comment: A glutamate-gated ion channel that mediates fast excitatory synaptic transmission. AMPA receptors are non-selective cation channels and their trafficking and phosphorylation state regulate synaptic strength.

@graph.rdfs:label: HS Cell
@graph.rdfs:comment: A horizontal system tangential cell in the fly lobula plate that responds to horizontal motion. HS cells integrate local motion detector signals and are involved in optomotor control during flight.

@graph.rdfs:label: VS Cell
@graph.rdfs:comment: A vertical system tangential cell in the fly lobula plate that responds to vertical motion. VS cells are numbered VS1-VS10 and tile the visual field with overlapping receptive fields.

@graph.rdfs:label: CH Cell
@graph.rdfs:comment: A centrifugal horizontal tangential cell in the fly lobula plate sensitive to front-to-back motion. CH cells integrate motion signals and contribute to visual course control.

@graph.rdfs:label: Retinal Ganglion Cell
@graph.rdfs:comment: Output neurons of the retina whose axons form the optic nerve and project to the brain. Retinal ganglion cells have diverse types with different temporal dynamics, receptive field properties, and projection targets.

@graph.rdfs:label: Granule Cell
@graph.rdfs:comment: The most numerous neuron type in the brain, located in the cerebellar cortex. Granule cells receive mossy fiber input and send parallel fibers that synapse onto Purkinje cell dendrites, forming a fundamental circuit for motor learning.

@graph.rdfs:label: Purkinje Cell
@graph.rdfs:comment: Large neurons with elaborate dendritic trees in the cerebellar cortex that are the sole output of the cerebellar cortex. Purkinje cells integrate parallel fiber and climbing fiber inputs and project to deep cerebellar nuclei.

@graph.rdfs:label: Climbing Fiber
@graph.rdfs:comment: Axons from the inferior olive that make powerful synapses onto Purkinje cell dendrites, with each Purkinje cell innervated by a single climbing fiber. Climbing fiber activity serves as a teaching signal for motor learning.

@graph.rdfs:label: Oxytocin Neuron
@graph.rdfs:comment: A neurosecretory neuron in the hypothalamus that releases oxytocin into the bloodstream from the posterior pituitary. Oxytocin neurons exhibit phasic bursting activity synchronized across the population.

@graph.rdfs:label: Vasopressin Neuron
@graph.rdfs:comment: A neurosecretory neuron in the hypothalamus that releases vasopressin (antidiuretic hormone) from the posterior pituitary. Vasopressin neurons exhibit phasic bursting with long burst durations.

@graph.rdfs:label: Electrosensory Lateral Line Lobe
@graph.rdfs:comment: The hindbrain structure in weakly electric fish that receives primary electrosensory input and contains pyramidal cells organized into topographic maps. The ELL processes amplitude modulations of the electric field.

@graph.rdfs:label: P-type Electroreceptor
@graph.rdfs:comment: A primary electrosensory afferent in weakly electric fish that encodes amplitude modulations with probability coding. P-type receptors respond to increases in amplitude with increased firing and show adaptation.

@graph.rdfs:label: Trigeminal Nucleus
@graph.rdfs:comment: The brainstem nucleus that receives primary sensory input from the whiskers via the trigeminal nerve. The trigeminal nucleus contains barrelettes corresponding to individual whiskers and projects to thalamus.

@graph.rdfs:label: Ventral Posterior Medial Nucleus
@graph.rdfs:comment: The thalamic nucleus in the rodent whisker pathway that receives input from trigeminal nucleus and projects to barrel cortex. VPM contains barreloids with topographic organization matching the whisker pad.

@graph.rdfs:label: Layer 4
@graph.rdfs:comment: The granular layer of cortex that receives the main thalamocortical input. In barrel cortex, layer 4 contains the barrelsâcytoarchitectonic structures corresponding to individual whiskers.

@graph.rdfs:label: F-I Curve
@graph.rdfs:comment: The frequency-current relationship showing how a neuron's firing rate depends on injected current. F-I curves distinguish Type I neurons (continuous at threshold) from Type II neurons (discontinuous at threshold).

@graph.rdfs:label: Synaptic Delay
@graph.rdfs:comment: The time delay between presynaptic action potential arrival and postsynaptic potential onset, typically 0.5-5 ms for chemical synapses. Synaptic delays contribute to temporal filtering and constrain the speed of neural computation.

@graph.rdfs:label: Spike Propagation
@graph.rdfs:comment: The movement of action potentials along axons and dendrites through regenerative activation of voltage-gated channels. Propagation velocity depends on myelination, axon diameter, and channel distribution.

@graph.rdfs:label: Myelination
@graph.rdfs:comment: The insulation of axons by myelin sheaths formed by oligodendrocytes or Schwann cells. Myelination dramatically increases conduction velocity through saltatory conduction at nodes of Ranvier.

@graph.rdfs:label: Axon Initial Segment
@graph.rdfs:comment: The region of the axon closest to the soma where action potentials are initiated due to high density of sodium channels. The AIS acts as the spike trigger zone and plays a key role in neuronal excitability.

@graph.rdfs:label: Active Dendrite
@graph.rdfs:comment: Dendrites containing voltage-gated channels that support active signal propagation and nonlinear integration. Active dendrites can generate local spikes, amplify inputs, and implement complex computations.

@graph.rdfs:label: Passive Dendrite
@graph.rdfs:comment: Dendrites that conduct signals primarily through passive cable properties without significant active conductances. Passive dendrites implement linear integration and filter high-frequency inputs.

@graph.rdfs:label: Electrical Synapse
@graph.rdfs:comment: Direct electrical connections between neurons formed by gap junctions. Electrical synapses allow bidirectional, fast transmission and synchronize neural activity.

@graph.rdfs:label: Chemical Synapse
@graph.rdfs:comment: Synapses where information is transmitted via neurotransmitter release and receptor activation. Chemical synapses allow amplification, modulation, and unidirectional transmission.

@graph.rdfs:label: Excitatory Synapse
@graph.rdfs:comment: Synapses that depolarize the postsynaptic membrane and increase firing probability. Excitatory synapses typically use glutamate as a neurotransmitter.

@graph.rdfs:label: Inhibitory Synapse
@graph.rdfs:comment: Synapses that hyperpolarize or shunt the postsynaptic membrane and decrease firing probability. Inhibitory synapses typically use GABA or glycine as neurotransmitters.

@graph.rdfs:label: Dale's Principle
@graph.rdfs:comment: The classical concept that a neuron releases the same neurotransmitter(s) at all its synapses. Modern understanding allows co-release of multiple transmitters but maintains that the sign of synaptic effect is consistent.

@graph.rdfs:label: Neurotransmitter System
@graph.rdfs:comment: The collection of molecular machinery and processes involved in chemical synaptic transmission, including synthesis, packaging, release, reuptake, and degradation of neurotransmitters.

@graph.rdfs:label: Glutamate
@graph.rdfs:comment: The primary excitatory neurotransmitter in the central nervous system, acting on ionotropic receptors (AMPA, NMDA, kainate) and metabotropic receptors. Glutamate mediates most fast excitatory transmission and plays key roles in plasticity.

@graph.rdfs:label: GABA
@graph.rdfs:comment: Gamma-aminobutyric acid, the primary inhibitory neurotransmitter in the brain, acting on GABA-A (ionotropic) and GABA-B (metabotropic) receptors. GABA mediates fast and slow inhibition and regulates neural excitability.

@graph.rdfs:label: Dopamine
@graph.rdfs:comment: A catecholamine neurotransmitter involved in reward, motivation, motor control, and cognition. Dopamine acts on D1-like and D2-like receptors and is implicated in addiction, Parkinson's disease, and schizophrenia.

@graph.rdfs:label: Serotonin
@graph.rdfs:comment: A monoamine neurotransmitter (5-HT) involved in mood, sleep, appetite, and various cognitive functions. Serotonin acts on multiple receptor subtypes and is targeted by antidepressant medications.

@graph.rdfs:label: Acetylcholine
@graph.rdfs:comment: A neurotransmitter acting on nicotinic (ionotropic) and muscarinic (metabotropic) receptors, involved in motor control, arousal, attention, and memory. Acetylcholine is the neurotransmitter at the neuromuscular junction.

@graph.rdfs:label: has delay
@graph.rdfs:comment: Specifies the temporal delay in signal transmission, such as synaptic delay or axonal conduction delay. This property characterizes timing in neural circuits.

@graph.rdfs:label: has conduction velocity
@graph.rdfs:comment: Specifies the speed at which action potentials propagate along axons, measured in meters per second. This property depends on myelination and axon diameter.

@graph.rdfs:label: has release probability
@graph.rdfs:comment: Specifies the probability that an action potential triggers neurotransmitter release at a synapse. Release probability varies across synapse types and is modulated by short-term plasticity.

@graph.rdfs:label: has binding affinity
@graph.rdfs:comment: Specifies the strength of binding between a ligand and receptor, typically expressed as a dissociation constant. This property characterizes neurotransmitter-receptor and calcium-buffer interactions.

@graph.rdfs:label: generates action potential
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates a neuron model or membrane to the action potentials it produces through the coordinated activity of ion channels. This property connects cellular mechanisms to their electrical output signals.

@graph.rdfs:label: determines excitability
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates membrane potential to the likelihood of action potential generation. This property describes how the electrical state of the membrane influences neuronal firing behavior.

@graph.rdfs:label: propagates along
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates an action potential to the neural structure along which it travels. This property describes the spatial spread of electrical signals through axons and dendrites.

@graph.rdfs:label: is modulated by myelination
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates spike propagation to myelination status which dramatically affects conduction velocity. This property captures how anatomical features influence signal transmission speed.

@graph.rdfs:label: initiates at
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates action potential generation to the axon initial segment where spikes are typically triggered. This property identifies the anatomical location of spike initiation.

@graph.rdfs:label: triggers release
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates action potentials to the synaptic vesicle release they induce through calcium influx. This property connects electrical signals to chemical transmission.

@graph.rdfs:label: enables transmission
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates vesicle release to the synaptic transmission process it mediates. This property describes the role of vesicle fusion in chemical communication.

@graph.rdfs:label: occurs during transmission
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates synaptic transmission to the temporal delay inherent in chemical transmission. This property characterizes the timing constraints of synaptic communication.

@graph.rdfs:label: regulated by calcium
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates vesicle release to calcium dynamics which control the probability and timing of neurotransmitter release. This property describes calcium-dependent mechanisms of synaptic transmission.

@graph.rdfs:label: influx through channel
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates calcium dynamics to the calcium channels that allow calcium entry into cells. This property connects molecular mechanisms to cellular signaling dynamics.

@graph.rdfs:label: stored in organelle
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates calcium dynamics to endoplasmic reticulum where calcium is sequestered and released. This property describes intracellular calcium stores and their role in signaling.

@graph.rdfs:label: supports burst generation
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates calcium dynamics to burst firing patterns which often depend on calcium-activated currents. This property connects cellular signaling to temporal coding patterns.

@graph.rdfs:label: generates dendritic spike
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates calcium channels in dendrites to the local dendritic spikes they can produce. This property describes active dendritic properties and nonlinear integration.

@graph.rdfs:label: implements coincidence detection
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates dendritic integration mechanisms to coincidence detection which requires temporal precision. This property describes computational operations performed by dendrites.

@graph.rdfs:label: governed by cable properties
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates dendritic signal propagation to the cable equation that describes voltage spread along dendrites. This property connects biophysics to mathematical descriptions.

@graph.rdfs:label: solved numerically
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates cable equation to numerical methods required for simulation since analytical solutions are rare. This property connects mathematical models to computational techniques.

@graph.rdfs:label: approximates by finite difference
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates cable equation to finite difference methods commonly used for spatial discretization. This property identifies specific numerical techniques for solving PDEs in neuroscience.

@graph.rdfs:label: modeled by stochastic process
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates neural variability and spike trains to stochastic processes that capture randomness. This property connects biological phenomena to their mathematical representations.

@graph.rdfs:label: approximated by Poisson
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates spike trains with random, independent firing to Poisson process models. This property identifies a common simplification for modeling irregular neural activity.

@graph.rdfs:label: captured by point process
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates spike trains to point process models that describe sequences of discrete events. This property connects neural data to statistical frameworks for analysis.

@graph.rdfs:label: characterized by intensity
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates point processes to their conditional intensity functions which specify instantaneous firing rates. This property describes the mathematical characterization of spike train models.

@graph.rdfs:label: validated by rescaling
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates point process models to the time-rescaling theorem used for goodness-of-fit testing. This property connects models to validation methods.

@graph.rdfs:label: assessed by goodness of fit
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates neuron models to statistical tests evaluating how well they match observed data. This property describes model validation procedures.

@graph.rdfs:label: selected by method
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates competing models to model selection criteria that balance fit and complexity. This property describes how researchers choose among alternative models.

@graph.rdfs:label: fitted by likelihood
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates models to likelihood methods used for parameter estimation from data. This property connects models to statistical inference procedures.

@graph.rdfs:label: analyzed for information
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates neural responses to information-theoretic analysis that quantifies coding capacity. This property connects neural coding to mathematical frameworks for information.

@graph.rdfs:label: quantified by mutual information
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates neural coding to mutual information measures that quantify stimulus information. This property describes how information content is measured in neural responses.

@graph.rdfs:label: measured by Shannon entropy
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates information theory to Shannon information which quantifies uncertainty. This property identifies fundamental measures of information in neural coding analysis.

@graph.rdfs:label: bounded by Fisher information
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates parameter estimation precision to Fisher information which sets fundamental bounds. This property describes limits on coding precision in neural systems.

@graph.rdfs:label: limited by sampling bias
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates information estimates to sampling bias which corrupts estimates with finite data. This property describes practical limitations in neural data analysis.

@graph.rdfs:label: visualized by PSTH
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates spike trains to peristimulus time histograms that display temporal response patterns. This property connects neural data to standard visualization methods.

@graph.rdfs:label: characterized by ISI
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates spike trains to interspike interval distributions that reveal firing regularity. This property describes temporal statistics of neural activity.

@graph.rdfs:label: exhibits oscillation
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates neural networks to rhythmic activity patterns they generate. This property connects network dynamics to oscillatory phenomena.

@graph.rdfs:label: produces gamma rhythm
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates balanced networks and inhibitory-excitatory interactions to gamma oscillations. This property describes specific frequency bands emerging from network dynamics.

@graph.rdfs:label: enables synchronization
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates oscillations to neural synchronization which coordinates activity across populations. This property describes how rhythmic activity binds distributed representations.

@graph.rdfs:label: analyzed by dynamics
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates neural networks to dynamical systems theory used for understanding their behavior. This property connects neural circuits to mathematical frameworks.

@graph.rdfs:label: has attractor state
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates dynamical systems to attractors which represent stable states or patterns. This property identifies the stable behaviors that systems converge to.

@graph.rdfs:label: implements working memory
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates attractor networks to working memory which relies on persistent activity states. This property connects network dynamics to cognitive functions.

@graph.rdfs:label: supports bistability
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates attractor dynamics to bistability which enables switching between states. This property describes multi-stable dynamics underlying memory and decisions.

@graph.rdfs:label: undergoes transition via bifurcation
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates bistable systems to bifurcations that create or destroy stable states. This property describes qualitative changes in dynamics as parameters vary.

@graph.rdfs:label: supports decision making
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates attractor networks and bistability to decision-making processes. This property connects neural dynamics to cognitive computations.

@graph.rdfs:label: implements Bayesian inference
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates decision-making and neural computation to Bayesian inference frameworks. This property describes normative theories of how brains process uncertainty.

@graph.rdfs:label: decoded by algorithm
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates population codes to decoding algorithms that read out represented variables. This property connects neural representations to computational readout mechanisms.

@graph.rdfs:label: approximated by mean field
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates large neural networks to mean field theory that reduces complexity. This property describes analytical approximations for population dynamics.

@graph.rdfs:label: processed in hippocampus
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates spatial coding and memory to hippocampal circuits that implement these functions. This property localizes cognitive functions to brain structures.

@graph.rdfs:label: processed in cerebellum
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates motor learning and coordination to cerebellar circuits. This property localizes motor control computations to the cerebellum.

@graph.rdfs:label: optimized by control
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates motor movements to optimal control theory that explains trajectories. This property connects behavior to normative computational principles.

@graph.rdfs:label: example movement
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates motor control principles to specific movements like saccades that exemplify them. This property provides concrete examples of motor control implementations.

@graph.rdfs:label: processed in visual cortex
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates visual feature extraction and receptive fields to visual cortex. This property localizes visual processing to cortical areas.

@graph.rdfs:label: implements motion detection
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates fly motion vision to correlation-based detection mechanisms. This property describes computational mechanisms in insect vision.

@graph.rdfs:label: modulates attention
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates saliency maps to attentional mechanisms that guide selection. This property connects bottom-up feature detection to attention.

@graph.rdfs:label: constrains information flow
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates attention to information bottlenecks that limit processing capacity. This property describes capacity limits in cognitive systems.

@graph.rdfs:label: implements gain modulation
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates attentional mechanisms to gain control that adjusts neural responsiveness. This property describes how attention modulates sensory processing.

@graph.rdfs:label: processed in barrel cortex
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates tactile processing to barrel cortex in rodent somatosensory system. This property localizes whisker-related sensory processing.

@graph.rdfs:label: processed in electrosensory
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates electric field detection to electrosensory system in weakly electric fish. This property localizes specialized sensory processing.

@graph.rdfs:label: studied in weakly electric fish
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates burst coding and feature extraction to weakly electric fish model systems. This property identifies organisms used for studying neural mechanisms.

@graph.rdfs:label: modeled by compartmentalization
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates neurons with spatial structure to compartmental modeling approaches. This property connects biological complexity to simulation strategies.

@graph.rdfs:label: simulated by molecular dynamics
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates ion channels at atomic resolution to molecular dynamics simulations. This property connects molecular structures to simulation methods.

@graph.rdfs:label: approximated by Brownian
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates ion permeation to Brownian dynamics which models thermal motion. This property identifies efficient simulation methods for ionic processes.

@graph.rdfs:label: computed by continuum model
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates electrostatic interactions around channels to continuum electrostatics methods. This property describes computational approaches for electrostatic calculations.

@graph.rdfs:label: constrained by Dale's principle
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates neurotransmitter systems to Dale's principle about consistent transmitter release. This property describes organizational principles of neural circuits.

@graph.rdfs:label: uses neurotransmitter system
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates synapses to the neurotransmitter systems they employ for chemical transmission. This property specifies the molecular basis of synaptic communication.

@graph.rdfs:label: approximated by Ornstein-Uhlenbeck
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates membrane potential fluctuations to Ornstein-Uhlenbeck diffusion processes. This property identifies stochastic models for subthreshold dynamics.

@graph.rdfs:label: Neural Microcircuit
@graph.rdfs:comment: A local network of interconnected neurons that performs specific computational operations. Microcircuits are fundamental building blocks of cortical processing and can be viewed as generic computational elements that transform inputs into outputs through recurrent dynamics.

@graph.rdfs:label: Liquid State Machine
@graph.rdfs:comment: A computational framework where recurrent neural circuits act as dynamic reservoirs that transform temporal input patterns into spatial activity patterns. Liquid state machines provide a non-Turing model of computation suitable for real-time processing of continuous input streams, with separation property ensuring distinct inputs produce different network states.

@graph.rdfs:label: Reservoir Computing
@graph.rdfs:comment: A computational paradigm where a fixed recurrent neural network (the reservoir) projects high-dimensional temporal inputs into a state space, followed by a trainable readout layer. This approach leverages the intrinsic dynamics of recurrent networks without training the recurrent connections themselves, providing efficient real-time computation.

@graph.rdfs:label: Temporal Integration
@graph.rdfs:comment: The process by which neural circuits accumulate information over time, combining past and present inputs to compute time-varying representations. Temporal integration is essential for processing temporal sequences and is naturally implemented by recurrent neural networks with fading memory.

@graph.rdfs:label: Kernel Function
@graph.rdfs:comment: A mathematical function that describes how past inputs influence current network state in a dynamical system. In the context of neural microcircuits, kernels characterize the fading memory property and determine the temporal integration window over which the network operates.

@graph.rdfs:label: Real-Time Computation
@graph.rdfs:comment: Computation performed on continuous input streams without waiting for complete input sequences, as required for online processing in biological systems. Real-time computation contrasts with traditional Turing machine models and is naturally implemented by recurrent neural microcircuits through their transient dynamics.

@graph.rdfs:label: Separation Property
@graph.rdfs:comment: A key requirement for neural microcircuits stating that different input streams should be mapped to network states that are sufficiently separated in state space. This property ensures that distinct inputs can be reliably discriminated by downstream readout mechanisms.

@graph.rdfs:label: Approximation Property
@graph.rdfs:comment: A computational property stating that a readout layer can approximate any desired time-varying function of recent inputs by linear combination of neural microcircuit states. This property, combined with separation, makes neural microcircuits universal computational elements for real-time processing.

@graph.rdfs:label: Episodic Memory
@graph.rdfs:comment: A memory system for personally experienced events bound to their spatial and temporal context. Episodic memory is critically dependent on the hippocampus and involves encoding, consolidation, and retrieval of unique episodes with specific contextual details.

@graph.rdfs:label: Pattern Completion
@graph.rdfs:comment: A computational process in associative memory networks where partial or degraded input cues trigger retrieval of complete stored patterns. Pattern completion is implemented by recurrent connections in attractor networks and is a key function of hippocampal CA3 region.

@graph.rdfs:label: Pattern Separation
@graph.rdfs:comment: A computational process that creates distinct representations for similar inputs, reducing interference and enhancing memory discrimination. Pattern separation is particularly associated with the dentate gyrus of the hippocampus, which has sparse coding and expansion recoding properties.

@graph.rdfs:label: Mixed Attractor Network
@graph.rdfs:comment: A neural network model containing both discrete attractors (for categorical memories) and continuous attractors (for analog representations). Mixed attractor networks can implement both item memory and continuous variables like head direction or spatial position within a unified framework.

@graph.rdfs:label: Reward System
@graph.rdfs:comment: A collection of brain structures involved in processing reward prediction, motivation, and reinforcement learning. The reward system includes dopaminergic neurons in the ventral tegmental area and substantia nigra that signal reward prediction errors and modulate synaptic plasticity.

@graph.rdfs:label: Reward Prediction Error
@graph.rdfs:comment: The difference between received and predicted reward, which serves as a learning signal in reinforcement learning. Dopamine neurons encode reward prediction errors and drive synaptic plasticity in target regions including striatum and prefrontal cortex.

@graph.rdfs:label: Feedforward Control
@graph.rdfs:comment: A motor control strategy that generates motor commands based on internal models without relying on sensory feedback during movement execution.
