Feedforward control enables rapid, ballistic movements and compensates for sensory delays, with the cerebellum playing a critical role in feedforward motor learning.

@graph.rdfs:label: Internal Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: A neural representation of the dynamic properties of the body or environment that enables prediction of sensory consequences of actions. Internal models include forward models (predicting sensory outcomes) and inverse models (computing required motor commands), and are essential for skilled motor control.

@graph.rdfs:label: Forward Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: An internal model that predicts the sensory consequences of motor commands, enabling anticipatory control and sensory prediction. Forward models allow the brain to estimate current state despite sensory delays and to distinguish self-generated from externally-caused sensory signals.

@graph.rdfs:label: Inverse Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: An internal model that computes the motor commands required to achieve a desired sensory state or movement trajectory. Inverse models solve the problem of transforming desired outcomes into appropriate muscle activations, a key component of motor planning.

@graph.rdfs:label: Motor Learning
@graph.rdfs:comment: The process of acquiring and refining motor skills through practice, involving adaptation of internal models and refinement of motor commands. Motor learning includes error-based adaptation (correcting for systematic errors) and use-dependent learning (reinforcement of successful movements), with cerebellar and basal ganglia contributions.

@graph.rdfs:label: Equilibrium Point Hypothesis
@graph.rdfs:comment: A theory of motor control proposing that the nervous system controls movements by specifying equilibrium positions for limbs through coordinated changes in muscle activation patterns. This hypothesis simplifies motor control by exploiting muscle visco-elastic properties and spinal reflexes.

@graph.rdfs:label: Cerebellar Model
@graph.rdfs:comment: A computational model of cerebellar function emphasizing its role as an adaptive filter or supervised learning system. Cerebellar models typically include parallel fiber inputs, Purkinje cell outputs, and climbing fiber teaching signals that drive synaptic plasticity for motor adaptation and coordination.

@graph.rdfs:label: Purkinje Cell
@graph.rdfs:comment: The principal output neuron of the cerebellar cortex, receiving excitatory input from parallel fibers and modulatory input from climbing fibers. Purkinje cells exhibit complex spike responses to climbing fiber input and simple spikes driven by parallel fibers, with plasticity at parallel fiber synapses underlying motor learning.

@graph.rdfs:label: Climbing Fiber
@graph.rdfs:comment: A powerful excitatory input from the inferior olive to cerebellar Purkinje cells that provides error signals for motor learning. Each climbing fiber makes extensive synaptic contacts on a single Purkinje cell, producing complex spikes that serve as teaching signals for long-term depression at parallel fiber synapses.

@graph.rdfs:label: Parallel Fiber
@graph.rdfs:comment: The axons of cerebellar granule cells that run parallel to the cortical surface and form synapses with Purkinje cell dendrites. Parallel fibers provide contextual sensory and motor information to Purkinje cells, with their synapses undergoing plasticity based on climbing fiber activity.

@graph.rdfs:label: Olfactory Bulb
@graph.rdfs:comment: The first central processing station for olfactory information, receiving direct input from olfactory receptor neurons and processing odor representations through mitral and tufted cells. The olfactory bulb exhibits oscillatory dynamics and implements lateral inhibition through granule cell circuits.

@graph.rdfs:label: Mitral Cell
@graph.rdfs:comment: The principal output neuron of the olfactory bulb that transmits processed odor information to higher olfactory areas. Mitral cells receive input from olfactory receptor neurons within glomeruli and are modulated by local interneurons including granule cells.

@graph.rdfs:label: Glomerulus
@graph.rdfs:comment: A spherical structure in the olfactory bulb where olfactory receptor neurons converge onto mitral and tufted cell dendrites. Each glomerulus receives input from receptor neurons expressing the same odorant receptor, providing the first stage of odor processing and creating a spatial map of odor features.

@graph.rdfs:label: Olfactory Receptor Neuron
@graph.rdfs:comment: A sensory neuron in the olfactory epithelium that expresses a specific odorant receptor and transduces chemical signals into electrical signals. Olfactory receptor neurons expressing the same receptor converge on common glomeruli in the olfactory bulb.

@graph.rdfs:label: Dentate Gyrus
@graph.rdfs:comment: A region of the hippocampal formation involved in pattern separation and sparse coding of episodic memories. The dentate gyrus contains granule cells that receive input from entorhinal cortex and project to CA3 via mossy fibers, implementing expansion recoding that enhances memory discrimination.

@graph.rdfs:label: CA3 Region
@graph.rdfs:comment: A hippocampal region with extensive recurrent connections that implements auto-associative memory and pattern completion. CA3 receives sparse input from dentate gyrus and dense input from entorhinal cortex, enabling both pattern separation and completion within a single network.

@graph.rdfs:label: CA1 Region
@graph.rdfs:comment: The main output region of the hippocampus that compares information from CA3 (memory retrieval) with current sensory input from entorhinal cortex. CA1 implements novelty detection and match-mismatch comparison, with output projections to subiculum and back to entorhinal cortex.

@graph.rdfs:label: Entorhinal Cortex
@graph.rdfs:comment: A cortical region that serves as the main interface between hippocampus and neocortex, providing spatial and non-spatial information to hippocampal circuits. The entorhinal cortex contains grid cells, border cells, and object-responsive cells that support spatial navigation and memory.

@graph.rdfs:label: Grid Cell
@graph.rdfs:comment: A neuron in entorhinal cortex that fires when an animal is at regularly spaced locations forming a hexagonal grid covering the environment. Grid cells provide a metric coordinate system for spatial navigation and combine with place cells to enable path integration and spatial memory.

@graph.rdfs:label: implements real-time processing
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates a neural microcircuit to its capability for real-time computation on continuous input streams. This property describes the computational paradigm where circuits process temporal information without waiting for complete sequences.

@graph.rdfs:label: has separation property
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates a computational system to its ability to map distinct inputs to separated states in representation space. This property is essential for enabling reliable discrimination and readout of different input patterns.

@graph.rdfs:label: performs temporal integration
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates a neural circuit to its function of accumulating information over time using fading memory. This property describes how recurrent dynamics enable integration of temporal input sequences.

@graph.rdfs:label: characterized by kernel
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates a dynamical system to the kernel function that describes its temporal response properties. This property specifies how past inputs influence current state through fading memory mechanisms.

@graph.rdfs:label: implements pattern completion
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates a neural network to its ability to retrieve complete patterns from partial cues through attractor dynamics. This property describes memory retrieval mechanisms in auto-associative networks.

@graph.rdfs:label: implements pattern separation
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates a neural region to its function of creating distinct representations for similar inputs. This property describes how sparse coding and expansion recoding reduce interference in memory systems.

@graph.rdfs:label: encodes reward prediction error
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates a neural system to its function of computing and signaling discrepancies between expected and received rewards. This property describes the role of dopaminergic systems in reinforcement learning.

@graph.rdfs:label: uses feedforward control
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates a motor system to its use of predictive control based on internal models rather than sensory feedback. This property describes anticipatory motor strategies that compensate for sensory delays.

@graph.rdfs:label: maintains internal model
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates a brain region to its representation of body or environment dynamics for motor prediction and control. This property describes neural substrates of forward and inverse models.

@graph.rdfs:label: undergoes motor learning
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates a neural system to its capacity for acquiring and refining motor skills through practice and error correction. This property describes adaptive processes that improve motor performance.

@graph.rdfs:label: provides teaching signal
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates climbing fibers to their role in supervised learning by providing error signals that drive cerebellar plasticity. This property describes the instructive input that guides synaptic modifications.

@graph.rdfs:label: processes odor information
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates neural structures to their role in olfactory processing and odor representation. This property describes the flow of chemosensory information through olfactory circuits.

@graph.rdfs:label: converges on glomerulus
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates olfactory receptor neurons to the glomerular targets where they synapse with mitral and tufted cells. This property describes the convergence that creates odor feature maps in the olfactory bulb.

@graph.rdfs:label: supports episodic memory
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates hippocampal circuits to their essential role in encoding and retrieving memories of personally experienced events. This property describes how spatial and temporal context is bound to memory representations.

@graph.rdfs:label: encodes grid pattern
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates entorhinal cortex neurons to their hexagonal firing pattern that provides a metric coordinate system for spatial navigation. This property describes the spatial representation that supports path integration.

@graph.rdfs:label: part of electrosensory system
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates weakly electric fish to their specialized sensory modality for detecting electric fields. This property connects the organism to its electrosensory processing capabilities.

@graph.rdfs:label: characterizes spike timing
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates interspike intervals to their role in describing temporal structure of spike trains. This property connects timing measurements to neural coding and variability analysis.

@graph.rdfs:label: input to CA3
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates dentate gyrus to its projection target in hippocampal CA3 region via mossy fibers. This property describes the flow of pattern-separated information into the auto-associative network.

@graph.rdfs:label: output to CA1
@graph.rdfs:comment: Relates CA3 to its projection target in CA1 region via Schaffer collaterals. This property describes transmission of retrieved memory patterns for comparison with current sensory input.
